Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Zeolite Thin Films as Efficient and Robust Ion Exchange Membranes in Redox Flow Batteries for Renewable Energy Storage

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1263860 / 1263707 Dong, Junhang / Murad, Sohail

The lack of economical and efficient energy storage devices is one of the major hurdles to the widespread utilization of renewable solar and wind energy. The redox flow battery (RFB) is an attractive option because of its excellent safety, high capacity, high efficiency, modularity, and small environmental footprint; however, in its current development state it is not commercially viable largely because of inefficiencies in the ion exchange membrane (IEM), which is a key factor determining its cost effectiveness, energy efficiency, and battery lifetime. Research and development efforts on IEMs for RFBs have largely focused on polymer-based materials. These materials have fundamental deficiencies, associated with their polymeric nature, related to ion crossover and chemical instability in high concentration electrolyte solutions of RFBs; therefore, alternative IEMs fabricated from new materials are required. The goal of this project is to explore nanoporous zeolite thin films as a new class of highly efficient and durable IEMs for RFBs. A key objective is to understand the mechanisms of proton conduction and field-driven ion transport in the zeolite membranes. The research will primarily focus on the siliceous MFI-type zeolite membranes for two model RFB systems including the Fe/Cr RFB and the all-vanadium RFB. The specific objectives include: (i) synthesizing MFI zeolite membranes with different thickness, orientation, and framework composition and investigating the effects of these structural and chemical properties on the membrane performance in RFBs; (ii) experimentally studying the transport properties for proton and relevant metal ions with and without applied electric fields; and (iii) performing molecular simulations of the electrical-field-driven and chemical-potential-gradient-driven ion transport processes. Zeolite membrane transport is governed by the field-driven diffusion of ?hydrated protons? in essentially non-ionic subnanometer zeolitic channels and is fundamentally different from the proton hopping process in the hydrated ionic polymers. This research will employ nanoporous inorganic membranes, particularly the crystalline zeolite membranes, as a new generation of highly efficient and robust IEMs for RFBs. The project will advance fundamental knowledge on ion transport in the zeolite membranes through synergistic efforts involving experimental studies and molecular dynamics simulations. Simulations will guide efforts to determine the most promising membrane structural and chemical properties.

Broader Impacts: If successful, this research may guide the design of storage devices for intermittent energy from renewable sources. The membranes developed will also have potential applications energy production and environmental protection. A more complete fundamental understanding of the electrical field-driven ion transport mechanism in zeolitic nanopores will be a significant contribution to membrane science. The project involves experimental and theoretical studies that will provide opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students. Plans have been made to incorporate the research findings into existing courses and to include undergraduate participation from diverse academic and ethnic backgrounds. Both PIs have outreach activities involving high school students and undergraduate students through research projects and presentations at seminars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1.    Technical Outcomes

The nanoporous zeolite thin films have been for the first time demonstrated as a new class of highly efficient and durable ion exchange membranes (IEMs, or ion separator) for redox flow batteries (RFBs) and understandings of the mechanisms of proton conduction and field-driven ion transport and separation in the zeolite membranes have been obtained. The crystalline zeolite membranes of sub-nanometer pore sizes have been proven to conduct proton with exceptionally high selectivity against metal ions by size-exclusion effect in electrolyte solutions relevant to RFBs. It has been revealed that the proton permeability and conductivity in the zeolite membrane depend strongly on the Si/Al ratio in the framework, which determines the zeolite surface hydrophilicity and internal concentration of exchangeable proton. The zeolite membranes with high Si/Al ratios, when used as IEM in the VRFB and FCRFB, have shown great potential for significantly enhancing the battery lifetime and energy efficiency because of the high proton selectivity, membrane thinness (hence low resistance), and exceptional chemical resistance. Extended research work has demonstrated that using electronically conducting porous carbon substrates as substrate may offer an effective way for practical utilization of zeolite membranes for high performance RFBs. It has also been shown that zeolite-polymer composite membranes could be an alternative means for exploiting the unique properties of zeolites for enhancing the IEM performance in RFBs.

The major technical findings of this project have been disseminated to the scientific community and industry through peer-reviewed publications, patents, Ph.D. dissertations, and presentations in major national and international conferences. The project has yielded six peer-reviewed journal publications, three Ph.D. dissertations, two U.S. patents (pending), and seven presentations in international and national scientific conferences.

 2.      Broad impact outcomes

2.1  Educational outcomes

Education and training of graduate and undergraduate students is another key objective of this project. Research activities of this project involve membrane (functional materials) synthesis and characterizations, membrane separation operations, mass transport measurements and modeling, electrochemical reactions, and battery operation and performance evaluations that provide excellent interdisciplinary learning opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students. This project has fully or partially supported four Ph.D. students, with three of them successfully graduated with Ph.D. degrees granted during the project term and the other one in second year of Ph.D. program.

The most significant scientific accomplishment and contribution of project is the first time demonstration of the size-exclusion-enabled high-selectivity conduction phenomena in crystalline zeolite membranes of sub-nanometer pores and the fundamental understandings of the ion transport behaviors in the membranes under electrolyte operation mode. Research of this project has revealed the relationships between the zeolite pore structure and surface chemistry and the ion separation and conduction performances of their membranes, which enriched the field of membrane science and technology. The findings of the ion separation mechanisms and applications of the microporous inorganic membranes as IEMs in RFBs and as ion separators for brain desalination have been incorporated into graduate/undergraduate courses including the “In organic Membranes” (UC course number: 20-ChE-6059/20-ChE-5059) and “Membrane Separation” (UC course numbers: 20-CHE-6060/20-CHE-5060), which are offered every year.

2.2  Technology transfer outcomes

A “License Agreement” has been established between the University of Cincinnati and the Bettergy Corp in New York for the zeolite-based ion exchange membranes developed through this project. This License Agreement is now effective and the technology transfer is been actively carried out. The technology transfer is based on patents filed (pending approval).

2.3  Research experiences for female and high school students

A female M.S. student was involved in this research for her M.S. theses (completed) and Ph.D. dissertation (in progress). A female chemical engineering undergraduate student at University of Cincinnati (UC) carried summer research program on this project in collaboration with the UC WISE-REWU program, and a high school student (from Sycamore High School, Cincinnati, Ohio) participated in summer research activities. The students learned skills in membrane materials synthesis and advanced characterization, membrane and batteries performance test and evaluations, model based performance data analysis, and technical writing and presentation. The students also gained knowledge on energy storage technology and nanostructured materials and experiences in interdisciplinary research and development.
